item.title: O/S No 159 the gutters are full of twigs & leaves the street needs sweeping, 26th June
item.description:
Resident reporting the street needs cleaning & sweeping it is full off leaves and branches & twigs. Resident is 88 and sweeps outside his property & the pavement. Gutters are full of twigs, papers, leaves & rubbish there is a bus stop on the same side & everything is thrown on the floor

item.description:

item.title: Two mattresses and a cushion, 26th June
item.description:
I have messaged many times and the mattresses have still not been removed. They were thrown into my garden by a man. I called the police. This was many weeks ago and the mattresses are still in my garden. The gate is unlocked, so please go in and remove!

Nearest address to the pin placed on the map (from OS Places API): Warwick Grove, Hackney, London

item.title: Outside 85 Holsworthy Square, 26th June
item.description:
This scaffolding has been here for at least half a year - the road is 6 foot 6 inch signed width restriction so it is hard to navigate - but made almost impossible by the red and white separator barriers that have been placed on the road! Right now since the north side of Holsworthy Square road is closed due to roadworks, traffic is forced to redirect and if this street is chosen, your vehicle will get scratched! There is no way to reverse back out. Private scaffolders shouldn't be allowed to significantly narrow the road when it is already as narrow as possible. Furthermore, there is no sign prohibiting a right turn when emerging onto Grays Inn Road - so a number of vehicles turn and only see that the road is closed going northbound. Completely thoughtless roadwork traffic management. Please contact the private scaffolding company - as I say its been months and nothing changed, and also the roadworks.

Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Mount Pleasant, Holborn, London
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: Permission, 26th June
item.description:
You have stated we can prune the tree back to our property line, we had someone come to give us a quote. He unfortunately expressed due to the work needing it would make the tree unsafe and unbalanced. Therefore he had quoted us on two jobs, please see invoice attached. We love the tree however his stated it’s only half the size and will continue to grow, we can not afford to keep cutting this back every 6-12months, he has given us the option of removing and planting a tree better for the area and environment. Please see attached. I have crossed out my private details. We would love the second option best, we would ensure the work is completed to the best standard and keep ontop of any future work needed with the trees. I have confirmed this is not a protected tree, and has no TPO. It’s classed as a street tree. But we can not prune it back to the property line due to half of the tree hanging over garden. The gentleman is fully insure ect - see attached. But he needs it in writing that we have permission.

Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Duddington Close, Elmstead, London
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: Flytipping, 26th June
item.description:
Dumped mattresses, rubbish, other household items in layby on Sidcup Road (Mottingham Road side). Fencing is broken too so layby and damaged fencing making it easy for folk to dump in the undergrowth. Smells bad and a threat to wildlife. So not environmentally friendly. The amount of flytipping is encouraging others despite Royal Borough of Greenwich 's Campaign regarding scrapping flytipping. Please sort and put in prevention strategies such as, repair fencing and put up warning including repercussions. Thank you
Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Sidcup Road, Middle Park, London
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: Council blue bag of rubbish uncollected, 26th June
item.description:
A blue bag of rubbish I presume collected by the council has been left on the pavement for the past two days. Foxes are now getting at it, and small bits of rubbish debris are collecting around it. This stretch of the street is a hot spot for fly tipping. If the council itself can't collect its own rubbish it sets a really bad precedent for other fly tippers, and we the residents suffer.

Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): 11, Copleston Road, London
Report on FixMyStreet
